creator: jks@iname.com
text:
If you accidentally have two Listen directives apache files to start with:

(98)Address already in use: make_sock: could not bind to address 0.0.0.0:80
no listening sockets available, shutting down
Unable to open logs

Instead a more useful error message should be generated.

I don't see great utility in complicating the code to give a better error
message in this (probably relatively rare) case.  You'd have to duplicate the
kernel's logic; it may be difficult w.r.t. IPv6 vs IPv4 addresses also (e.g.
does [::]:80 w/o IPV6_V6ONLY conflict with 0.0.0.0:80?).  A FAQ entry would be
better.
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
Eh.  FAQs are for /frequently/ asked questions ;-)

I really don't see this as a confusion that many people run into.
creator: slive@apache.org

text:
I'm inclined to say that this is moderately frequently asked. It comes up 3-5
times a week on IRC. I'll take responsibility for "fixing this in
documentation".  A more detailed error message would be nice, but I'll take
Joe's word that this would be hard.
creator: rbowen@apache.org

text:
Rich, are you sure about this?

I see users confused about this error message all the time.  But it is almost
always because:
- They have another webserver running; or
- They already have apache running and are trying to start it again.

This is the only report I have ever seen of someone confused by duplicate Listen
directives.
creator: slive@apache.org
rbowen@apache.org
text:
I've been watching for this over the last couple months. It doesn't come up as
often as I had previously thought, but it does turn out to be the problem most
of the time that people see this error. I'll attempt to add a small remark about
this in the Listen doc and get this closed. Sorry for the long inactivity.

Something like "Multiple Listen directives will cause an 'Address already in
use' error message, and cause the server to fail on startup.'
A brief remark about this added in the documentation: revision 105884. Closing.
creator: rbowen@apache.org
